job_title: Deputy Manager in London, England
pros:
Great opportunities to develop professionally.
Line managers/directors (in my experience) are accessible & approachable.
cons:
Departments/people can be very territorial, which can stunt great change.
Told to "stay in your lane" on various occasions.
No real sense of teamwork.

job_title: State Apartment Warder in Hampton Court, England
pros: A unique and beautiful place to work
cons: Cronyism is rife as is bulling. The management are uncaring unless you are their friend. Security management are racist.

job_title: Retail Assistant in Hampton Court, England
pros: Great experience and pay per hour.

job_title: Director in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: Great, like a dream job

review_title: Managers Treat Staff Unfairly and Inconsistently In Some Cases
job_title: State Apartment Warder in East Molesey, England
pros: The pay is slightly better than the National Trust and English Heritage but who knows how much longer that will continue with the complusory redundancies...
cons:
Staff who criticise HRP or who question things are frequently singled out as “trouble-makers” which fosters a culture of fear throughout the organisation. Bullying is a major problem in some departments which HRP seems reluctant to address.
Sickness absence is something HRP is extremely strict about. Some staff with absences related to their disability are given disciplinary warnings.

job_title: Explainer in London, England
pros:
Beautiful surroundings
Good amount of breaks
Kind colleagues
cons:
Weekend working
Boredom when not busy
Not great for moving up within the company

job_title: Assistant Manager in London, England
pros: The people the team the tower
cons: Long hrs can have a negative impact on your work and life balance

job_title: Warden in London, England
pros: Great colleagues and fun atmosphere
cons: Long hours and very busy, physically demanding

job_title: Security Officer in London, England
pros: If you like history good place to work
cons: Management are awful and treat you poorly

job_title: Digital Producer in Worcester, England
pros: Strong shared purpose among staff. Above-average pay in heritage sector for office roles and world-renowned place to work. Great mentoring and learning opportunities, and they actively encourage internal and external secondments.
cons: Office spaces can be quite dated, but that is normal in the heritage sector!

job_title: State Apartment Warder in Hampton Court, England
pros: Beautiful building and gardens. Some good colleagues.
cons: If you become friends with your manager and go to the pub with them you will do well, even if you are incredibly lazy, in fact you will get promoted. Vile cronyism. Those who work hard do not reap rewards. You have to be a favourite to do well.

job_title: B2B Sales Executive in London, England
pros: Free tickets for the palaces
cons: Not much diversity in Waterloo block

review_title: Lovely people, lovely place to work
job_title: Public Engagement Assistant in London, England
pros:
Working with a vibrant, diverse set of people 
Working in beautiful, historic environments
Pay is better than most zero-hour contracts
cons:
Work is mainly centred around school holidays
Depends on what events are being run, no guarantee of paid work

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in London, England
pros: Small friendly team. No two days are the same.
cons: Overworked....not much of a work/life balance available.

job_title: State Apartment Warder in Richmond, London, England
pros: Working in a world famous historic venue
cons: Having to deal with the gross favouritism showed to friends and favourites, by the Team Leaders.

job_title: Press Executive in London, England
pros: Lovely people and beautiful building with so much history
cons: No opportunity to grow or be promoted due to outdated pay structure

job_title: Senior Technical Team Lead in Hampton Court, England
pros: The Palace is a great place to work. Your might find yourself lost in the first few days.
cons: Can't think of any issues with HRP

review_title: A very good charity to work for!
job_title: Retail and Admissions Assistant in London, England
pros: Getting to work at some of the top tourist desinations in the UK. Oppurtunites to complete cross-departmental work. Collegues were like minded, which is a bonus.
cons: Communication between TL and employees could be improved.

job_title: Household Assistant in Lisburn, Northern Ireland
pros: Very Relaxed and friendly place to work.
cons: No cons Everything was brilliant.

job_title: Gift Shop Assistant/Stock Controller in Kensington, England
pros:
Chance to work in beautiful places and historic buildings.
Get to learn a lot about the history of the various sites, left job having a wider knowledge of the historical relevance of the places.
Easy shift, either 9.30-17.30 or 10.30-18.30.
Got to visit sites free of charge in spare time.
Get to interact with visitors from wide variety of places.
Colleagues very nice people.
Specific training on items sold in gift shop.
cons:
Kensington Palace became very hot in the summer.
There could be very slow days in the off season.
Extremely high level of customer service expected, this was difficult to do when busy.
The constant need to hound customers and ask if they needed help was unnecessary, there would be some customers who would be approached 3-4 times by different people. 
Too much focus on mystery shopper scores, it really isn't as important as management think it is.
Manager had no people skills.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hillsborough, Northern Ireland
pros: Given how much of a draw working life at a royal palace is, HRP have their pick of the cream of the crop really. Their strong recruitment framework is focussed on drawing in good people with initiative, personality and know-how. I have genuinely loved every moment here.
cons:
Being the palace 'across the water' in a London-centric charity, it can feel that decision making processes are guided by a very different culture to our own in NI.

As others have suggested, career progression is limited. This is inevitable in a company with such a strong, dependable work environment where staff turnover is very low. What I would highlight though is the experience you can gain from the company through training and HR initiatives such as interdepartment learning days is invaluable and could offer a great stepping stone to those willing to look for progression outside HRP.

review_title: Probably the most bias review you're going to read on this page!
job_title: Resource Manager in London, England
pros:
I am part of the resourcing team here at HRP but just wanted to highlight what makes this the best place I've ever worked at;

The places I go to work in each day are actual Palaces and there is truly so much energy around them from the people who visit and the events we manage to the charitable work we do engaging with the public and preserving the palaces.

Everybody works together to support each other - it genuinely is a place you make friends for life.

The pay is good the perks are even better

Each day is different with new and exciting stories and challenges to take on

Its hard to find anything else quite like it I think.....
cons: People stay, so it can restrict internal progression opportunities at times

job_title: Contracts and Procurement Manager in London, England
pros: Staff are leaders in their fields, very dedicated, passionate and knowledgeable. It's a treat to work with such people. As an organisation, HRP provides staff training and support as well as excellent benefits and perks. There's also always something exciting going on, never a dull moment!
cons: At times the workload can be intense, because there is so much going on. All teams are constantly striving to do their best and more, which can be challenging.

review_title: Fun team and fascinating place to work
job_title: Seasonal Sales Assistant in London, England
pros: The people I worked with were lovely and the organisation and support received was brilliant. They were very conscientious with training and always offering new opportunities to learn more about the history of the palaces.
cons: One of our store managers was notoriously lazy and incompetent which everyone seemed aware of but because of how long she'd worked there no-one was willing to reprimand her. Though it never directly affected my work it certainly would have done if I'd stayed longer.

job_title: Business Receptionist in Hillsborough, Northern Ireland
pros:
rates of pay higher than national trust
pleasent surroundings
cons:
Cliquey. People worked in silos, most likely to enjoy your work if your face fitted
toxic atmosphere for some staff members (security for ex.)
No prospect of advancement for staff at all (even before COVID 19)
hypocritical management, bad representation, compulsory redundancy scheme

review_title: Six palaces, an innovative approach and some really interesting projects.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros: Independent of government funding, so able to set its own priorities. Strongly driven to attract and engage visitors. More commercial sense than many in the not-for-profit sector.
cons: Managers' ability and interest in managing people highly variable. Certain vanity projects without any real merit get approved because of who champions them.

job_title: Ops in London, England
pros:
interesting buildings and nice people. 
No two days are the same which is good.
Salaries when compared to similar sectors is on average or better.
Salaries reviewed annually.
cons:
Not very keen on flexible working.
No work life balance.
Decisions take a long time to be made as it can be very bureaucratic.
Very difficult to be promoted due to the structure of the departments.
Heavily unionised

job_title: State Apartment Warder in East Molesey, England
cons: The bare bones of the Warding role can be monotonous but it is what you make it. Interaction with visitors and the prestige of the venues, makes this role unforgettable.

job_title: Retail Sales Assistant in London, England
pros:
Community atmosphere.
Deputy team leaders are most often fair managers with good people skills.
cons:
Higher management in chaos and often with a superiority complex.
Technology so old it hinders the work process.
Communication across departments is almost nonexistent.
Work culture not encouraging.

review_title: A phenomenal organisation with a great cause
